atum_entry.description: Companies structure their organization into separate functions or entities that ATUM refers to as business units. This layer maps services to business units to provide business owners with the cost and consumption view of the IT products and services they use.

atum_entry.name: infra_services
atum_entry.label: Infrastructure Services
atum_entry.description:
The scope and breadth of the Infrastructure Services defined is based on two key points:

  1. The Service taxonomy should support different IT organization structures (e.g. Centralized vs. Distributed / Federated).

    As such, for a centralized IT organization, the direct customers for many infrastructure services may be internal IT itself and not others outside of IT.

    Shared IT organizations (infrastructure and operations) will have external groups as direct consumers of the infrastructure services.

  2. The objective is to define a standard service taxonomy across the variety of public cloud IaaS offerings.

    Many of the newer services created to categorize the public cloud services may not be applicable for some internal IT organizations.

The ATUM Services layer is comprised of a four tier hierarchy to organize and classify the various services that IT typically provides.

  1. Service Type is the top level of the services hierarchy. This aggregates services based on focus domain like business, technology etc.
  2. Service Category is the second level in the services hierarchy. This represents common groupings of services based on sub-domains within each of the Service Types.
  3. Service Name is the third level of the services hierarchy. Represents the primary Services provided by the IT organization. Each service may have one or more specific Service Offerings, which provide choice for the service.
  4. Service Offering is the fourth and lowest level of the services hierarchy. The Service Offering represents the specific, different available options for a service.

The different Service Offerings within a specific service provide a choice to the business consumers where they are able to select based on differences in the product, capabilities, services levels and associated cost or pricing.

A few examples might include: Ultraportable Laptop, Standard Laptop, Gold/Silver/Bronze Email.
atum_entry.label: Services
atum_entry.name: services

atum_entry.name: lan_wan
atum_entry.label: LAN/WAN

uom_list.description:
An active port is a port on a switch or router that has been activated and/or enabled so that a device can use it. A port may be active even if it is not currently in use. For example, LAN ports are considered active even if a user is not currently seated at the hot-desk (or hotel desk).

A network switch or ”blade” (card) in a switch chassis is not considered active if hard or soft MAC activity (e.g. applying power to switch); physically patching the switch; or applying policies (QoS or VLAN) for the network is required for its operation.

These are collected separately by type of device on each tab, and they are a calculated field on the Peer Selection Survey.

The high level definition is included here, and detailed definitions are included for each device type.

An end user device is a device used by a user. The primary purpose of a WAN is to connect end user devices to each other, and to central resources such as servers and storage.

The number of end user devices (EUDs) includes

  1. All PCs, terminals, thin clients, PDAs, smartphones and tablets that can be connected to the LAN
  2. All network connected printers
  3. Wireless access points (count each as one end user device)
  4. The maximum number of concurrent Remote Access ports
  5. Other user or customer peripheral devices such as ATMs, POS terminals.

When a router is operated by IT on a third party premises, the number of EUDs for this router is 1. A typical example is when a Bank installs one of its routers on a clearing house premises, to guarantee secure communications.

Do not include the following in the count of end user devices:
  1. Servers - Volumes for Servers connected to the WAN are collected separately in the Compute Tower
  2. Routers and switches (not usually in the hands of users)

A Wireless Access Point (WAP) is a device that allows wireless devices to connect to a wired network using Wi-Fi or related standards conforming to IEEE 802.11. The WAP usually connects to a router (via a wired network), and can relay data between the wireless devices (such as computers or printers) and wired devices on the network.

Concurrent Remote Access Ports refers to the number of Remote Network Access ports for dial-in (the maximum number of simultaneous remote connections), supporting VPN or similar access

atum_entry.name: mobile_devices
atum_entry.label: Mobile Devices

list: Systems analysts/engineers providing technical operations & support
Systems analysts/engineers providing technical operations & support

atum_entry.description:
Client mobile devices, including smart phones (iOS, Android, Windows Mobile), tablets, and PDAs. A mobile device is a handheld mobile device that is used to deliver end user computing functionality such as email, browsing or media access. Examples of mobile devices are smartphones, tablets, PDAs and palmtops.

Smartphone: A smartphone is a mobile phone which has email, browsing and media access functionality (e.g. BlackBerry, iPhone, Android HTC phone, Win7 Mobile, etc.).

Tablet: A tablet is a mobile device that does not have a keyboard or hard drive, (i.e. touch screen only). Examples include the iPad, Samsung Galaxy, Lenovo ThinkPad, HTC Flyer, Sony Tablet etc. Even if the device is used to access common office applications via Citrix, it would still be captured in here.

If the “tablet” device has an attached keyboard and a hard drive, it should be counted as a laptop in Workspace. Examples include the Tablet PCs from Dell and Lenovo. These devices are essentially next generation laptop replacements and considerably extend the functionality of the devices so that they can be used more easily for word processing, spreadsheet production etc.

PDA: PDAs (Personal Digital Assistants) are small, handheld computers such as PalmPilots, iPAQs, other Win7 Mobile handhelds, and Psion organizers without phone capability.

atum_entry.name: it_towers
atum_entry.label: IT  Towers

sources.cost centers: A cost center is a department or "sub unit" of a company that is held accountable for the expenditures required to run the department or group. The Cost Center and an understanding of the organizational responsibility of the cost center are used to assign or apportion some of the costs from the GL to the appropriate IT Resource Tower.

atum_entry.description: The IT Resource layer represents the discrete components of what IT buys, builds and operates to deliver services to the business. The costs for labor, hardware, software, and other resources are organized into IT Resource Towers (e.g. servers, storage, desktop, app dev, etc.) to determine the total cost of ownership (TCO) and the unit costs for internal and peer comparison. This layer is a standardized way of looking at common functions of IT that perform certain types of work and are responsible for specific outcomes. IT towers define broad classes of IT technical capability that is expected to remain relatively unchanged as IT organization evolves over time. Sub towers are often tied to a particular implementation decision—mainframe or servers, deliver the capability modeled by the broader ‘Compute’ tower.

atum_entry.name: internal_labor
atum_entry.label: Internal Labor
atum_entry.description: Internal Labor includes the full range of personnel costs and activities required for delivering or supporting the IT services – including direct operational activities, support and management and administration activities.

atum_entry.name: external_labor
atum_entry.label: External Labor
atum_entry.description: External Labor includes the full range of external personnel costs and activities required for delivering or supporting the IT services – including direct operational activities, support and management and administration activities.

atum_entry.name: consulting
atum_entry.label: Consulting
atum_entry.description: External consulting project-based services typically delivered through a statement of work.

atum_entry.name: cloud_service_provider
atum_entry.label: Cloud Service Provider
atum_entry.description: External public cloud service providers including IaaS, PaaS and SaaS.

atum_entry.name: outside_services
atum_entry.label: Outside Services
atum_entry.description:
Outside services costs include IT services that are purchased from external service providers.

Do not include maintenance costs for hardware or software, these should be recorded in the appropriate hardware or software cost sub-pools.

Neither should the costs of employing temporary or contract staff be included in this cost pool, such costs are included in the external labor cost pool.

Examples of outside services include managed network services, cloud storage for end user backup, externally provided email services.

Any costs for the retained function should be recorded in the appropriate towers, and the costs associated with managing the contract and the vendor relationship should be included in IT Management – Vendor Management.

atum_entry.name: hw_expense
atum_entry.label: Expense
atum_entry.description: Hardware expense of non-capitalized equipment purchases (e.g. spare parts, consumables or equipment below capitalization threshold).

atum_entry.name: hw_lease
atum_entry.label: Lease
atum_entry.description: Hardware rental or lease expenditures (e.g. hardware purchased through a supplier via a financial leasing arrangement).

atum_entry.name: hardware
atum_entry.label: Hardware
atum_entry.description:
All physical assets (excluding property, office space or raised floor facilities) are included in this cost pool.

The range of assets will vary by tower, but examples include servers, PCs, storage arrays, network appliances, printers and so on.

Where a device contains embedded software (firmware), for example in a network firewall, the cost should be reported as hardware even if the software can be upgraded for a separate fee.

atum_entry.name: sw_depreciation
atum_entry.label: Depreciation & Amortization
atum_entry.description: Software depreciation of capitalized software license purchases & software development efforts.

atum_entry.name: software
atum_entry.label: Software
atum_entry.description:
All software assets including operating system, middleware, databases, tools and utilities and applications.

Software costs include enterprise or per instance licenses, client-access licenses, maintenance/update costs, customization fees and Software as a Service (SaaS) fees.

atum_entry.name: fp_expense
atum_entry.label: Expense
atum_entry.description: Data center space, power, security and other operating expenses (e.g. co-location facility services, electricity, water, etc.).

atum_entry.name: fp_depreciation
atum_entry.label: Depreciation & Amortization
atum_entry.description: Data center depreciation of facility build and lease hold improvements (e.g. raised floor investments, power/PDU infrastructure, rack build-out).

atum_entry.name: facilities_power
atum_entry.label: Facilities & Power
atum_entry.description: Facilities & power costs include the floor space as well as the power, cooling, and other utilities costs, environmental control (fire suppression), power distribution, rack infrastructure, outside services and personnel costs related to managing the data center environment.

atum_entry.name: tel_expense
atum_entry.label: Expense
atum_entry.description: Operational expenses related to telecom like usage costs

atum_entry.name: tel_lease
atum_entry.label: Lease
atum_entry.description: Lease costs related to telecom like like leased lines.

atum_entry.name: telecom
atum_entry.label: Telecom
atum_entry.description:
The telecom cost pool is for the reporting of all telecommunications charges, including leased line, domestic and international voice (including mobile), MPLS, ISP and other charges.

Telecom costs include the circuits and any associated usage fees for providing voice and/or data telecommunication services between data centers, office locations, the internet and any customer, supplier or partner.

This is typically transmission across the wide area network (WAN).

atum_entry.name: other
atum_entry.label: Other
atum_entry.description:
Miscellaneous or non-standard expenses including additional taxes, non-data processing equipment, industry-specific data processing equipment, one time charges like workforce reductions, relocations & retirements, data subscriptions (ex: DnB) and outsourced business functions (BPO) like payroll.

Note: every effort should be made to use the main cost pools for identifying costs at the cost pool layer.

atum_entry.name: cost_pools
atum_entry.label: Cost Pools

sources.general ledger: IT related General Ledger line items, typically just for the IT cost centers. These include operating expenses and capital expenditures that are incurred by the IT organization.  The primary fields required to allocate costs include:  Period (when), Account (what), Cost Center (who) and Amount.  Additional key fields may include vendor and project identifiers if available.

sources.chart of accounts: The chart of accounts (COA) is the published list of the accounts used by an organization to define each class of items for which money is spent or received.  It is used to organize and segregate expenditures, revenue, assets and liabilities.   Each of the accounts used by the IT organization is assigned to one of the cost pools.

sources.budget/forecast: The budget of IT is typically compiled annually to help the company meet its plans.  The budget is an estimate of the amount of financial resources, including operating expenses and capital, to run the IT organization for the year and to support planned initiatives and projects.  Actual costs can be compared to budget to identify variances from plan and help IT take corrective actions.

atum_entry.description:
The Finance layer represents the investment view of IT and predicts and tracks what is spent to run IT, add capacity and build new capabilities.

When modelling IT costs, cost data is brought from the business’ accounting systems like the General Ledger (GL).

The GL consists of a list of accounts used by the organization to define each class of items for which money is spent.

The Financial layer is the base layer of the taxonomy that maps this cost source data, based on these accounts, into standard cost pools (e.g. labor, hardware, software, etc.)

These cost pools are the key drivers used to map costs from the financial layer to the other layers within the ATUM taxonomy.

atum_entry.name: atum
atum_entry.label: ATUM
atum_entry.description:
Apptio TBM Unified Model (ATUM) defines an IT business model to help the Office of the CIO run IT as a business. The concept of a unified model is in response to the pain points heard from our customers, members of the Technology Business Model (TBM) Council, partners and analysts: that there really is no easy way to classify and model IT’s costs and plans for communicating with the business, tracking improvements over time or comparing to external benchmarks.

ATUM is a core part of Apptio’s applications and is critical for the integration of costing, planning and billing; and forms the basis for modeling consistency, application upgrades, benchmarkable comparisons and support through user communities.ATUM is not a software product. It defines the elements of the IT business model. ATUM is instantiated in the TBM applications developed by Apptio. ATUM will have an evolving specification. This specification will have versions and will be aligned with and driven by the roadmap of our products. ATUM will evolve and adapt to the changing IT landscape across IT trends, application needs, customer input and the maturing of the TBM discipline. Segment specific instantiations of ATUM (e.g. Vertical industry segments, Fed) will be treated separately.

Specifically, ATUM includes the following:

  • Organizing Taxonomy: categorization of the elements that define the IT business model (e.g. cost pools, resource towers and services) and their relationships
  • Data: The datasets and definitions required to construct the IT business model
  • Key Drivers and Allocations: the drivers and interdependencies that define the cost composition of the entities and the allocation of these costs within the IT business model
  • Standardized TBM metrics and KPIs: to measure the performance of IT.
  • Extensibility: the ability to extend the above, within constraints, to accommodate changing trends in IT and customer needs
